title: 5 Indian Authors You Need To Know About In 2017
text:
facebook 339 SHARES 
Updating our book pile is always a fun task, especially when we have a whole lot of exciting titles to watch out for . This year, there are also some fun, new desi authors to add to the reading marathon. From romance, to tales of struggle, here are five Indian authors you need to put on that book wish list. 1. No Other World by Rahul Mehta 
Rahul Mehta came in the limelight with his excellent book, Quarantine , which was a short story collection about being gay in India. His new novel is about an Indian American boy, Kiran, who explores life as a gay Indian in the heart of America, in New York city. 
Buy the book here 2. Erotic Stories for Punjabi Widows by Balli Kaur Jaswal 
Twenty-year-old Nikki's life is going along just fine when her father dies unexpectedly, and she is expected to help her family financially. She takes up the job of teaching a creative writing course at a local community college in UK. However, the students aren't what she expected. Her class is filled with Sikh widows who wish to learn English. The result? Here is a class filled with a bunch of widows reading erotic fiction. 
Buy the book here 3. The Windfall by Diksha Basu 
The story beings with Mr. And Mrs. Jha, who have just moved to a new house in Gurgaon (Delhi). Coming from a small apartment to a super posh community, the two are struggling to fit in with these extremely wealthy and complete OTT North-Indian gang. 
Buy the book here 4. Pashmina by Nidhi Chanani 
The Young Adult graphic novel narrates the story of Priyanka, an Indian American teenager who is a complete nerd and living with her mother. The story goes beyond the typical Indian kid, stuck between modern American way of life and age old values, and instead focuses on the story of Priyanka's mom who is struggling to make ends meet, and Priyanka, who is dealing with this not too comfortable way of life and the relationship between them. Some really good stuff for a graphic novel, don't you think? 
Buy the book here 5. The Library of Fates by Aditi Khorana 
This is a retelling of an old Indian folk tale; the story of Amrita, a princess who puts herself out there to make sure her people are happy, only to be abandoned by them all. She is given a golden chance to reverse her fate, and the story focuses on her struggle to choose between changing her own destiny or fulfilling her duty as a princess.
